segment.source: Test and update an AppLocker policy (Windows 10)
segment.target: Test and update an AppLocker policy (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic discusses the steps required to test an AppLocker policy prior to deployment.
segment.target: This topic discusses the steps required to test an AppLocker policy prior to deployment.

segment.source: Test and update an AppLocker policy
segment.target: Test and update an AppLocker policy

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic discusses the steps required to test an AppLocker policy prior to deployment.
segment.target: This topic discusses the steps required to test an AppLocker policy prior to deployment.

segment.source: You should test each set of rules to ensure that the rules perform as intended.
segment.target: You should test each set of rules to ensure that the rules perform as intended.

segment.source: If you use Group Policy to manage AppLocker policies, complete the following steps for each Group Policy Object (GPO) where you have created AppLocker rules.
segment.target: If you use Group Policy to manage AppLocker policies, complete the following steps for each Group Policy Object (GPO) where you have created AppLocker rules.

segment.source: Because AppLocker rules are inherited from linked GPOs, you should deploy all of the rules for simultaneous testing in all of your test GPOs.
segment.target: Because AppLocker rules are inherited from linked GPOs, you should deploy all of the rules for simultaneous testing in all of your test GPOs.

segment.source: Step 1: Enable the Audit only enforcement setting
segment.target: Step 1: Enable the Audit only enforcement setting

segment.source: By using the Audit only enforcement setting, you can ensure that the AppLocker rules that you have created are properly configured for your organization.
segment.target: By using the Audit only enforcement setting, you can ensure that the AppLocker rules that you have created are properly configured for your organization.

segment.source: This setting can be enabled on the Enforcement tab of the AppLocker Properties dialog box.
segment.target: This setting can be enabled on the Enforcement tab of the AppLocker Properties dialog box.

segment.source: For the procedure to do this, see Configure an AppLocker policy for audit only.
segment.target: For the procedure to do this, see Configure an AppLocker policy for audit only.

segment.source: Step 2: Configure the Application Identity service to start automatically
segment.target: Step 2: Configure the Application Identity service to start automatically

segment.source: Because AppLocker uses the Application Identity service to verify the attributes of a file, you must configure it to start automatically in any one GPO that applies AppLocker rules.
segment.target: Because AppLocker uses the Application Identity service to verify the attributes of a file, you must configure it to start automatically in any one GPO that applies AppLocker rules.

segment.source: For the procedure to do this, see Configure the Application Identity Service.
segment.target: For the procedure to do this, see Configure the Application Identity Service.

segment.source: For AppLocker policies that are not managed by a GPO, you must ensure that the service is running on each PC in order for the policies to be applied.
segment.target: For AppLocker policies that are not managed by a GPO, you must ensure that the service is running on each PC in order for the policies to be applied.

segment.source: Step 3: Test the policy
segment.target: Step 3: Test the policy

segment.source: Test the AppLocker policy to determine if your rule collection needs to be modified.
segment.target: Test the AppLocker policy to determine if your rule collection needs to be modified.

segment.source: Because you have created AppLocker rules, enabled the Application Identity service, and enabled the Audit only enforcement setting, the AppLocker policy should be present on all client PC that are configured to receive your AppLocker policy.
segment.target: Because you have created AppLocker rules, enabled the Application Identity service, and enabled the Audit only enforcement setting, the AppLocker policy should be present on all client PC that are configured to receive your AppLocker policy.

segment.source: The Test-AppLockerPolicy Windows PowerShell cmdlet can be used to determine whether any of the rules in your rule collection will be blocked on your reference PCs.
segment.target: The Test-AppLockerPolicy Windows PowerShell cmdlet can be used to determine whether any of the rules in your rule collection will be blocked on your reference PCs.

segment.source: For the procedure to do this, see Test an AppLocker policy by using Test-AppLockerPolicy.
segment.target: For the procedure to do this, see Test an AppLocker policy by using Test-AppLockerPolicy.

segment.source: Step 4: Analyze AppLocker events
segment.target: Step 4: Analyze AppLocker events

segment.source: You can either manually analyze AppLocker events or use the Get-AppLockerFileInformation Windows PowerShell cmdlet to automate the analysis.
segment.target: You can either manually analyze AppLocker events or use the Get-AppLockerFileInformation Windows PowerShell cmdlet to automate the analysis.

segment.source: To manually analyze AppLocker events
segment.target: To manually analyze AppLocker events

segment.source: You can view the events either in Event Viewer or a text editor and then sort those events to perform an analysis, such as looking for patterns in application usage events, access frequencies, or access by user groups.
segment.target: You can view the events either in Event Viewer or a text editor and then sort those events to perform an analysis, such as looking for patterns in application usage events, access frequencies, or access by user groups.

segment.source: If you have not configured an event subscription, then you will have to review the logs on a sampling of computers in your organization.
segment.target: If you have not configured an event subscription, then you will have to review the logs on a sampling of computers in your organization.

segment.source: For more information about using Event Viewer, see Monitor application usage with AppLocker.
segment.target: For more information about using Event Viewer, see Monitor application usage with AppLocker.

segment.source: To analyze AppLocker events by using Get-AppLockerFileInformation
segment.target: To analyze AppLocker events by using Get-AppLockerFileInformation

segment.source: You can use the Get-AppLockerFileInformation Windows PowerShell cmdlet to analyze AppLocker events from a remote computer.
segment.target: You can use the Get-AppLockerFileInformation Windows PowerShell cmdlet to analyze AppLocker events from a remote computer.

segment.source: If an app is being blocked and should be allowed, you can use the AppLocker cmdlets to help troubleshoot the problem.
segment.target: If an app is being blocked and should be allowed, you can use the AppLocker cmdlets to help troubleshoot the problem.

segment.source: For both event subscriptions and local events, you can use the Get-AppLockerFileInformation cmdlet to determine which files have been blocked or would have been blocked (if you are using the Audit only enforcement mode) and how many times the event has occurred for each file.
segment.target: For both event subscriptions and local events, you can use the Get-AppLockerFileInformation cmdlet to determine which files have been blocked or would have been blocked (if you are using the Audit only enforcement mode) and how many times the event has occurred for each file.

segment.source: For the procedure to do this, see Monitor Application Usage with AppLocker.
segment.target: For the procedure to do this, see Monitor Application Usage with AppLocker.

segment.source: After using Get-AppLockerFileInformation to determine how many times that a file would have been blocked from running, you should review your rule list to determine whether a new rule should be created for the blocked file or whether an existing rule is too strictly defined.
segment.target: After using Get-AppLockerFileInformation to determine how many times that a file would have been blocked from running, you should review your rule list to determine whether a new rule should be created for the blocked file or whether an existing rule is too strictly defined.

segment.source: Ensure that you check which GPO is currently preventing the file from running.
segment.target: Ensure that you check which GPO is currently preventing the file from running.

segment.source: To determine this, you can use the Group Policy Results Wizard to view rule names.
segment.target: To determine this, you can use the Group Policy Results Wizard to view rule names.

segment.source: Step 5: Modify the AppLocker policy
segment.target: Step 5: Modify the AppLocker policy

segment.source: After you have identified which rules need to be edited or added to the policy, you can use the Group Policy Management Console to modify the AppLocker rules in the relevant GPOs.
segment.target: After you have identified which rules need to be edited or added to the policy, you can use the Group Policy Management Console to modify the AppLocker rules in the relevant GPOs.

segment.source: For AppLocker policies that are not managed by a GPO, you can use the Local Security Policy snap-in (secpol.msc).
segment.target: For AppLocker policies that are not managed by a GPO, you can use the Local Security Policy snap-in (secpol.msc).

segment.source: For info how to modify an AppLocker policy, see, Edit an AppLocker policy.
segment.target: For info how to modify an AppLocker policy, see, Edit an AppLocker policy.

segment.source: Step 6: Repeat policy testing, analysis, and policy modification
segment.target: Step 6: Repeat policy testing, analysis, and policy modification

segment.source: Repeat the previous steps 3–5 until all the rules perform as intended before applying enforcement.
segment.target: Repeat the previous steps 3–5 until all the rules perform as intended before applying enforcement.

segment.source: Additional resources
segment.target: Additional resources

segment.source: For steps to perform other AppLocker policy tasks, see Administer AppLocker.
segment.target: For steps to perform other AppLocker policy tasks, see Administer AppLocker.
